[[Brooklyn]], [[New York City|New York]], [[United States]] | death_date = | instrument = [[Piano]], [[Human voice|vocals]] | genre = [[Boogie-woogie]], [[jump blues]], [[jazz]] | occupation = [[Pianist]], [[singer]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = Early 1980s-present | label = [[Blind Pig Records|Blind Pig]], various | associated_acts = | website = [http://www.mitchwoods.com/devl/swf_html/index.html Link] }} '''Mitch Woods''' (born April 3, 1951, [[Brooklyn]], [[New York City|New York]], [[United States]]) is an [[United States|American]] modern day [[boogie-woogie]],{{cite book | first= Paul | last= Du Noyer | year= 2003 | title= The Illustrated Encyclopedia of Music | edition= 1st | publisher= Flame Tree Publishing | location= Fulham, London | isbn= 1-904041-96-5 | page= 166}} [[jump blues]] and [[jazz]] [[pianist]] and [[singer]].{{cite book | first= Paul | last= Du Noyer | year= 2003 | title= The Illustrated Encyclopedia of Music | edition= 1st | publisher= Flame Tree Publishing | location= Fulham, London | isbn= 1-904041-96-5 | page= 181}} Since the early 1980s he has been touring and recording with his band, the Rocket 88s.{{cite news|publisher=San Francisco Chronicle|title=MITCH WOODS SWINGS TO THE BIG EASY BEAT|author=Mark Hedin|date=May 21, 2006|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2006/05/21/PKGN3IR3UA1.DTL}} Woods calls his music, "rock-a-boogie," and with his backing band has retrospectively provided a 1940s and 1950s jump blues style.{{cite web |first= |last= |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p583/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Biography by Bill Dahl & Stephen Thomas Erlewine |publisher=Allmusic.com |accessdate=December 22, 2009}} ==Biography== Woods got his start playing clubs near the [[University at Buffalo, The State University of New York|State University of New York]] Buffalo campus. He moved to [[San Francisco]] in 1971.{{cite news|publisher=San Francisco Chronicle|title=Mitch Woods Whether playing solo or with his bands, Bay Area pianist rockets to New Orleans and back, then around the world|author=Derk Richardson|date=December 13, 2007|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/12/12/NS29TOONB.DTL}} Originally a student of jazz and [[classical music]], on relocation to the [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]], Woods started playing jump and [[rhythm and blues]]. Upon hearing [[Louis Jordan]]'s jive, Woods played throughout the 1970s as a [[solo (music)|soloist]] at local [[nightclub|clubs]]. In 1984, [[Blind Pig Records|Blind Pig]] released the debut [[album]] of the Rocket 88s, the band he had formed with HiTide Harris four years earlier. ''Steady Date with Mitch Woods & His Rocket 88s'' led to a national concert tour, including the [[San Francisco Blues Festival]] in 1985, as well as several European engagements. In 1988, they issued their second LP, ''Mr. Boogie's Back in Town.'' In 1991 their third album, ''Solid Gold Cadillac,'' was released, followed by ''Shakin' the Shack'' (1993). Woods, capable in four styles of piano playing, [[Chicago blues]], [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]] boogie-woogie, West Coast jump blues and the poly-rhythmic accents of [[New Orleans]], got the opportunity to play with some of his musical heroes, when he recorded his 1996 Viceroy album, ''Keeper of the Flame.''[http://www.mnblues.com/profile/mitchwoods-pf99.html Mnblues.com - accessed December 2009] Their next album, ''Jump for Joy,'' appeared in 2001. The 2006 release, ''Big Easy Boogie'' featured veteran New Orleans musicians backing Woods.{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r837316/review|pure_url=yes}}|title=Allmusic ((( Mitch Woods > Big Easy Boogie > Review )))}} In 2007 Woods was nominated for the Pinetop Perkins Piano Player of the Year Award at the Blues Awards in [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]], [[Tennessee]], presented by the [[Blues Foundation]].[http://mitchwoods.com/biography.htm Mitchwoods.com - accessed December 2009] Latterly he and his band toured with the ''[[Efes Beverage Group|Efes Pilsen]] Blues Festival''.[http://blog.efespilsen.com.tr/2010/10/04/efes-pilsen-blues-festival-ile-blues-firtinasi-basladi Efes Pilsen Official Blog - accessed October 2010] ==Discography== *''Steady Date with Mitch Woods & His Rocket 88s'' (1984) - [[Blind Pig Records|Blind Pig]] *''Mr. Boogie's Back in Town'' (1988) - Blind Pig *''Solid Gold Cadillac'' (1991) - Blind Pig *''Shakin' the Shack'' (1993) - Blind Pig *''Keeper of the Flame'' (1996) - Viceroy Records *''Jump for Joy!'' (2001) - Blind Pig *''Big Easy Boogie'' (2006) - Club 88 Records *''Jukebox Drive'' (2008) - El Toro *''Gumbo Blues'' (2010) - +1 Records{{cite web|url= {{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p583/discography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Allmusic ((( Mitch Woods > Discography > Main Albums )))}} *feat. on ''Jumpin' with friends'' (2012) with The Red Wagons, Junior Watson, Sugar Ray Norcia, Lynwood Slim, Igor Prado, Sax Gordon Beadle. ==See also== *[[List of boogie woogie musicians]] *[[List of jump blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p583/biography|pure_url=yes}} Biography] at [[Allmusic]] *[http://www.mitchwoods.com/devl/swf_html/index.html Official website] {{Authority control|VIAF=79952967}} {{Persondata | NAME =Woods, Mitch | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION =[[United States|American]] [[boogie-woogie]], [[jump blues]] and [[jazz]] musician | DATE OF BIRTH =April 3, 1951 | PLACE OF BIRTH =[[Brooklyn]], [[New York City|New York]], [[United States]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Woods, Mitch}} [[Category:1951 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American blues pianists]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American jazz pianists]] [[Category:Songwriters from New York]] [[Category:Jump blues musicians]] [[Category:Boogie-woogie pianists]] [[Category:People from Brooklyn]] [[Category:Musicians from New York]]
